free_text.Content: Biomechanics at the body level (functional anatomy; joint kinematics; forces in the joints). Biomechanics at the tissue level (large deformations; passive and active constitutive laws; identification; laws of evolution). Biomechanics in clinical applications (orthopaedics biomechanics; traumatology, implant development). Mini-project in group.
free_text.Type of teaching: The course is organised as theoretical sessions and includes the resolution of exercises and the realization of a mini-project within a group.
free_text.Learning outcomes: [b]Domain Skills:[/b][br/][li]Illustrate the biomechanical function of the different systems that form the human body, B1[br/][li]Explain the link between the physiology and the mechanical properties of a tissue, B2[br/][li]Calculate the kinematics and the forces in articulations, B3[br/][li]Identify the mechanical behaviour of tissues and fluids from experimental data, B5[br/][li]Propose or develop specific constitutive laws, B7[br/][li]Describe the feedback loop that, starting from a mechanical signal translated into a chemical signal, allows for the adaptation of the mechanical properties of tissues, B9[br/][li]Compute the stresses and strains at the interface of an implant and in the surrounding tissues, B10[br/][li]Compute the kinematics and forces in an implant, B11[br/][li]Describe the procedure to identity a constitutive law, B14[br/][b]Transversal skills:[/b][br/][li]Do a literature review and assess the state of the art, T4[br/][li]Write a scientific or technical report, T6[br/][li]Make an oral presentation, T7[br/][li]Analyse the consequences of a decision or solution, T20
